aaS 3 yes A rep can see that a billing account used to have a payment term of net 30 and now (due to a recent change performed by billing operations) has a payment term of net 45. Insights into Billing Account field history might provide reps some measure of actionable insight into how they quote them on amendments and renewals. 80.100 System shall show account payment info from Z-AR aaS 3 yes Insights into customer payment history. Did the customer pay their invoices on time, or are they getting behind on invoices? An answer to that question might reduce the willingness of sales to give higher discretionary discounts. 80.110 System shall show sales rep an approximate calculated sales compensation from Z-CPQ system 4 yes Sales reps would like to understand how much money they earn when they sell a deal. Feedback to the sales rep, when they manipulate discounts, affects their compensation payment and helps them to find alternative strategies to sell the deal. 80.120 System shall identify and show churn risk of this customer from Z-Metrics aaS 2 yes How many support tickets, how many calls to customer service, ratings of the product, etc.? Consumption is declining and not meeting the ramp criteria, so give more favorable discounts in case the churn risk is high.

Quote Deal Room

The Deal Room is another key differentiator, although there is a clear trend among existing CPQ solution providers to adopt the Deal Room concept as a better way to keep the customer engaged and, present quote proposals, and get faster feedback on the proposed deal from the prospect.  Another key advantage is the ability to post-marketing and supplemental information that supports the prospect in making a decision.  A Deal Room conveys a higher degree of professionalism and allows for more flexibility in quote proposal presentation and interaction levels with the prospect.   Of course, the traditional PDF generation of a quote proposal shall still be available in the Next Gen CPQ, as many Zuora customers use it today, and it is still the most used mechanism to present a quote to the prospect.

Deal Room - HLD

ID Requirement Priority MVP Notes 100.10 Sales Rep shall be able to publish a quote proposal to the Deal Room in Z-CPQ system 2 yes Sales reps can publish a quote as a proposal in a Deal Room. The same requirement exists for quote management. 100.20 Sales Rep shall be able to define key display characteristics of the quote proposal, and how it is displayed in the deal room in Z-CPQ system 3 yes Sales reps can decide what values and quote lines they want to show to the customer. For example, they might decide not to show list prices and discounts but just effective Prices. Sales reps might decide to add marketing content to be published. 100.30 System shall send notification via email with a link to the Deal Room to the Account sold-to Contact in Z-CPQ system 2 yes The sold-to contact will receive an email with a link to the secure Deal Room. 100.40 Customer Buyer shall be able to allow account sold-to contact to access the Deal Room in Z-CPQ system 2 yes Allow the contact to view the Deal Room content. Not every sold-to contact is allowed to sign the agreement. Let's say the contact is from the IT department w/o procurement permission. In order to sign the deal, the IT person has to invite one or multiple people from the procurement and finance departments to sign the deal. 100.50 System shall display the quote proposal in deal room in Z-CPQ system 2 yes The system displays the proposal as generated by the sales rep from the quote to the customer contact. 100.60 Customer Buyer shall be able to compare various quote alternatives in Z-CPQ system 2 yes Allow prospect user to compare two (or more) quote versions to understand how they differ in their key metrics. 100.70 System shall display related marketing materials about products and company in Z-CPQ system 4 yes The sales rep might decide to add marketing-related content (Product Datasheets, Whitepapers, etc) to be available for the contact to view in the Deal Room. 100.80 Customer Buyer procurement shall be able to allow contact to comment on a quote proposal in Z-CPQ system 2 yes Contact can place comments on the quote lines of the proposal 100.90 Customer Buyer shall be able to allow contact to deselect products from quote proposal in Z-CPQ system 3 yes Contact can remove products from the quote, marking them as not applicable. They can select a reason why they don't want the product. However, the interaction shall be limited to a few interactions with the quote proposal. 100.100 Customer Buyer shall be able to allow contact to add products (recommended) to a quote proposal in Z-CPQ system 3 yes Contact can add products. One way how to add is by making a recommended product active for the quote. Another method is to browse, filter, search the catalog, and add products that way 100.110 Customer Buyer manager shall be able to allow contact to invite coworkers to view quote proposal in Z-CPQ system 3 yes Contact might have others in his organization that need to see the proposal (e.g., corporate lawyer, engineers, purchase org) to decide if the proposal is what they need 100.120 Customer Buyer shall be able to allow contact to reject a quote proposal in Z-CPQ system 2 yes If a contact rejects a proposal, they also need to indicate why they reject it, needs further clarification, the price is not met, the product does not fit, lost interest, etc 100.130 Customer Buyer procurement shall be able to allow contact to view T&Cs of the quote proposal in Z-CPQ system 3 yes Contact can review the T&Cs that are associated with the quote 100.140 Customer Buyer procurement shall be able to Allow contact to edit (redline) T&Cs of the quote proposal in Z-CPQ system 4 yes Contact can make edits to the T&Cs, initiating a red-line process. A paragraph representing a T&C can be changed 100.150 Customer Buyer manager shall be able to allow contact to eSign the quote proposal in Z-CPQ system 3 yes Enable integration with common eSignature solutions like DocuSign and Certify. Not every buyer person might be allowed to sign the final contract. 100.160 Customer Buyer shall be able to allow contact to place an order in Z-CPQ system 3 yes The order shall be placed into Z-Order Management. The user gets confirmation that the order has been placed. The system sends a confirmation email with an order acknowledgment form.

Quote Deal Desk

Deal desk personnel are the company's authority in structuring a deal and getting exceptions approved.  As they are power users in the system, they need a few additional special functions compared to sales reps.  The real value of a deal desk function and the deal desk-specific UI is the quick understanding of the quote parameters, like quote metrics, and the reasons why the system flagged a quote with an exception.  They need to be able to drill from the general quote level metrics to the most specific quote line item level in an easy way.  Often, the deal desk is allowed to override certain quote rules to ‘make a deal happen.’  As companies restrict their sales reps to follow strict company rules and policies, deals desk personnel can make exceptions and, if needed, override company policies.   Having said that, in most cases, the deal desk sends a quote back to the sales rep with requests for changes to stay within given margins and soft policies.  Soft policies are rules a company has established that are not enforced in the CPQ system.  For those soft policies, rules do not exist in the CPQ system, but are known to sales reps and the deal desk, who manually check if they are adhered to.

ID Requirement Priority MVP Notes 110.10 System shall provide task list for rule-based flagged quotes in Z-Workflow 2 yes Users can easily create another alternate quote from an existing quote. They can make changes to the quote and then compare key metrics data. 110.20 System shall provide quote exception reports in Z-Workflow 2 yes Provide a flexible way to generate a deal score (on the quote level). MVP will allow customers to define their own deal score formula in an extension point 110.30 Deal Desk admin shall be able to create and compare quote versions in Z-CPQ system 2 yes Users can write notes on the line item level. If possible, users can mention them, and the system sends an alert email to the mentioned user. 110.40 Deal Desk admin shall be able to view Deal Score in Z-CPQ system 2 yes Users can request approval and review from another user who is not part of the approval workflow. 110.50 Deal Desk admin shall be able to capture internal notes in Z-CPQ system 3 yes The user approves or rejects a quote after review. This is a typical workflow action. A rejection will send the quote back to the sales rep; an approval will route the quote to the next approver. 110.60 Deal Desk admin shall be able to request ad-hoc approval in Z-CPQ system 4 yes Users can request approval and review from another user who is not part of the approval workflow 110.70 Deal Desk admin shall be able to accept and reject quote in Z-CPQ system 2 yes User approves or rejects a quote after review. This is a typical workflow action. A rejection will send the quote back to the sales rep, an approval will route the quote to the next approver. 110.80 Deal Desk admin shall be able to override certain quote rules in Z-CPQ system 3 yes There are certain business policies that are enforced by quote rules. A deal desk person shall be able to override those rules and make changes to a quote. This override function shall only be possible for designated rules.

Approval Workflow

Approval workflows are managing the collaboration between various actors who have a stake in the quote.  The sales rep will always initiate an approval workflow.  In most cases, business rules and an HR reporting hierarchy govern the approval sequence.  However, using the HR hierarchy is not a necessity to determine the approval sequence,

and hence, it is not asked for in this PRD.  The most typical interaction a user has with a workflow task is the approval or rejection of a quote, but it might not be limited to just an approval versus rejection action.  An ad-hoc workflow task is very valuable as it allows users like sales reps and customer buyer contacts to include ad-hoc other people in their organization to contribute to the quote.  The simplest form of contribution is to comment at the quote or line item level.  Comments can provide direction for the sales rep and customer buyer to make changes to the quote or quote proposal.  For MVP, comment ability on quote and quote line item is sufficient.

The most provided feedback from our customers is the lack of having two or more parallel approval task generated by our current SFDC-based simple Approval Workflow.  This capability shall be regarded as the main item out of all here requested capabilities.  Additionally Approval Memory and Line Level approvals (approver accepts a specific quote line instead of the entire quote) are advanced concepts that can bring tremendous benefits to the users of an Approval Workflow.   They also provide a competitive edge over other approval workflows that do handel parallel approval tasks but not any other advanced functionality.

Going forward, the ability to route a quote from person to person shall be referred to as Approval Workflow.

ID Requirement Priority MVP Notes 120.10 Sales Rep shall be able to request a Quote Approval (only sequential tasks) in Z-Workflow 1 yes Enable a sequential approval flow that requests approvals from users one at a time, determining approval levels based on quote attributes. 120.11 Sales Rep shall be able to determine user or user group who needs to approve an approval task in Z-Workflow 3 yes Supports administrators to use relationships e.g. quotes that are created by a sales rep who belongs to the west coast sales team shall be approved by the sales manager who leads the west c

ast sales team. Based on such expressed relationships, a workflow task is assigned to the correct user or user group. 120.20 Sales Rep shall be able to request a Quote Approval (with parallel tasks) in Z-Workflow 3 yes Enable a parallel approval flow that requests approvals from multiple users at the same time. 120.30 System shall initiate an approval escalation in Z-Workflow 2 yes Escalate approval requests in case no approval decision is obtained within a given time frame. 120.40 System shall apply Approval Memory in Z-Workflow 3 yes Do not re-request approval from approvers who already approved a quote if the quote has no 'relevant' changes since their last approval. 120.50 Sales Rep shall be able to initiate an Ad-hoc Approval in Z-Workflow 3 yes The user adds another user as an approver or reviewer. 120.60 System shall estimate approval time in Z-Workflow 4 yes When creating a quote, sales reps should know if their quote takes a short or long time to get approved based on similar quotes. This helps them communicate with their customers about the expected quote turnaround time. 120.70 System shall send email notifications with tasks for users in Z-Workflow 2 yes The user receives an email with a task. These emails are needed to ensure users are following up on their workflow items. 120.80 System shall allow approval or rejections via email reply in Z-Workflow 3 yes A user wants the convenience to just reply to an email with some keywords like 'Approved' or 'Rejected' to accomplish a workflow task. This should be enabled without the user being logged into the system. 120.90 System shall display progress of approval in quote in Z-Workflow 3 yes Visual feedback is needed to show the owner of the quote where the approval workflow is currently. Preferably, there is an estimate that tells the sales rep how much time is still left to get all approvals done. 120.100 System shall enable users to approve specific quote lines via workflow in Z-Workflow 3 no The Approval Workflow investigates quote line items and flags items that require approval. The system assigns an approval task and an approver to the line. The approver shall get an approval task for only the quote line. Approval status shall be rolled-up to the quote level.

AI Framework

The AI Framework provides the underlying capability to use AI at various points during the quote experience.  The AI Framework must be able to support various AI methods, from Agntic AI, Predictions to LLM.

ID Requirement Priority MVP Notes 130.10 System shall provide an AI Framework in Z-Metrics aaS 3 yes Provide tools that allow Zuora customers to train LLM and prediction models. 130.20 System shall recommended Products in Z-Metrics aaS 3 yes The system does a proximity search to recommend other similar products based on past quotes and orders. 130.30 System shall discount Guidance in Z-Metrics aaS 3 yes The system recommends a manual discount that is within the discount guidance and ensures a high probability of winning the deal. 130.40 System shall quote creation with AI prompt in Z-Metrics aaS 3 yes The entire quote with lines is created by the sentence, 'Create me a quote that has 20 ATMs that are suitable for moist conditions and apply a 10% discount.' 130.50 System shall adjust stored AI prompts in Z-Metrics aaS 3 yes This might be needed if the results with the applied prompt are not satisfying. This way, the customer admin can optimize the experience for the customer sales rep. 130.60 System shall training, learning, or fine-tune AI models in Z-Metrics aaS 3 yes This might be needed to train the model to improve the results and to make the model specific to the customer.

Quote Rules, Settings & User Admin

Besides product and solution configuration rules, the new CPQ system shall provide quote-level rules.  Quote-level rules are important as they enforce policies that are not restricted to a subset of quote lines.  Quote-level rules apply to the entirety of the quote.  A typical quo

e-level rule is the enforcement of a company policy where an amendment has to be the same or greater in value than the current ramp, subscription, or quote.

The ability to define these types of rules, the setup of quote behavior via system configuration parameters, and the assignment of CPQ profiles to users are part of this area.

Rules can produce errors and warnings and suggest messages for users to act on. 140.20 System shall define Subscription Level Rules in Z-Metrics aaS 1 yes Rules are defined by an admin to validate subscription-level fields. Rules can produce errors and warnings and suggest messages for users to act on. 140.30 System shall define Product rules in Z-Metrics aaS 1 yes Rules are defined by an admin that validates Product-level fields. Rules can produce errors and warnings and suggest messages for users to act on. 140.40 System shall define Ramp rules in Z-Metrics aaS 1 yes Rules are defined by an admin that validates Product-level fields. Rules can produce errors and warnings and suggest messages for users to act on. 140.50 System shall provide UI for user to setup an Approval Workflow in Z-Metrics aaS 1 yes Admin can set up work tasks for approval workflows using user roles. Workflows are triggered by quote field content.

Direct - Quote Request Flow

Zuora must enable self-service sales and quote request scenarios as part of the Omnichannel story.  Typically, prospects like to conduct research on possible products, services, and solutions before they contact specific solution providers.  In most cases, if the solutions are of higher complexity or the deals are large in nature, prospects want to engage with a sales rep.  Of course, transitioning from a self-service buying to an assisted sale scenario is ripe for agentic AI, and Zuora shall also consider how to handle incoming quote requests on an AI-driven automated basis.  The majority of incoming requests will be about price and, secondly, inquiries if a product supports a specific use case the customer has.   

From an interaction point of view, self-service prospects might not be registered users in the Zuora CPQ system.  

From a UI point of view, many of the UIs used for quoting can be reused.  For example, the entire catalog search, configuration, and selection experience can be reused.  Since many of the Zuora customers already have commerce portals deployed, it is unlikely that they will just use the Zuora-provided eCommerce applications.  

The likely scenarios of how the Zuora catalog is used with existing Customer e-commerce portals are as follows:

Zuora customers will digest products and prices via export from Zuora and import into their e-commerce systems.  Biz logic and UI are rendered in the Customer e-commerce system.

Zuora customers will use Zuora public Catalog APIs to retrieve product and price information. Biz logic and UI are rendered in the Customer e-commerce system.

Zuora customers will use Zuora public CPQ APIs and UI to provide a product configuration experience.  Solution configuration experiences are most likely not supported in a self-service scenario; hence, a lower-priority

Zuora customers will use their own shopping cart and check-out functionality. Hence, the focus is not on those areas for the CPQ MVP, and some basic shopping carts are needed for demos.

This is usually provided by an existing eCommerce system deployed by and owned by Zuora customers. This requirement is for a sample portal implementation and not part of the CPQ product offering to facilitate demos. 150.20 System shall access self-serv widgets provided by Zuora 3 yes Typical widgets that allow the interaction of a self-service user with a Zu

This is typically done in the shopping cart, but requesting a quote can also be offered as part of the catalog experience on the product detail page. 150.70 System shall create a Quote in Z-CPQ system 2 yes When a user requests a quote instead of placing an order, the customer commerce system generates a quote in Zuora CPQ. 150.80 System shall initiate and process a Sho

ping Cart check-out 5 no Typical check-out with payment and order confirmation. This shall not be implemented for Zuora CPQ MVP.

Indirect - SPR

The indirect sales process will focus on the high-tech 2-tier distribution channel.  This is the most relevant channel for Zuora's existing customers and, hence, has already been requested by Zoom and ??? to be supported by the current Zuora CPQ solution.

There are a variety of processes that a system can support in regard to selling partner channel management. Still, Zuora will stay focused on the transactional aspect of partner channel management.  In other words, Zuora is not planning to build functionality to manage selling partner relationships, which is typical for PRM solutions.

The next-gen CPQ solution will enable the publishing of products and prices to disti portals.  This allows distis to provide a catalog search, select and add products to a quote that is provided and managed in a disit provided quoting system.  It is not expected that distis will use Zuora CPQ UI to facilitate a quoting experience for VAR sales reps who are quoting on their portal.  

That is the reason why some requirements state that they are only sample implementations used to demo the functionality of the process and Zuora public APIs that facilitate only a part of the quoting process.

A major transactional process that is in scope is the support for distis to make Special Pricing Requests (SPRs).  SPRs are almost identical to a quote request, but they focus on the aspect of pricing (request higher discounts to better compete in deals) and not as much on what products are quoted.  Rounding up the SPR process is the ability to place an order for a service in Zuora.

Another major aspect is the support for marketplaces that are sponsored and provided by a large high-tech distributor such as Ingram Micro and Arrow.  These marketplaces offer a large product catalog with products from all vendors (=Zuora CPQ customers). The disti has a rel

tionship.  Now, the unique aspect of a marketplace is the ability to provide products via vendor-provided APIs, eliminating the need to import product prices and a lot of SKUs for a valid configuration of configurable products.  Simple product configuration provided by vendor APIs consumed by disti marketplaces is often preferred over large SKU imports.   That’s why there are specific requirements in this PRD for supporting catalog experience (getting prices for SKUs) and product configuration experience via productized APIs.

The purpose is to show how a VAR sales rep can create a quote for configurable products and solutions with ramps. Also, quotes for renewals and amendments can be in scope. 160.40 Sales Rep shall send quote with SPR# via email in Partner Portal 3 yes A disti sales rep will create for the VAR quote an SPR. The order must have the SPR # as a reference to get the agreed favorable price as requested via the SPR. Normally, placing an order with suppliers is done from the disti procurement system. Hence, this is just the ability to receive an order request from the disti. 162.70 System shall in Partner Portal 3 yes A channel ops person generates exports of products and prices that can be imported into a disti portal. This is an alternative way that distis can provide a catalog experience on their portal to VAR sales reps with solution providers' products.

User Management

The Next Gen CPQ will adopt the Multi Org functionality as implemented in the current CPQ.  Managing users should be centralized for all Zuora applications.  SSO solution integration shall be supported.

Functional Focus of NextGen CPQ

A recent conversation highlighted the main challenge with the existing CPQ-X (CPQ) system, as explained by the architect. It has many intricacies and complexities due to its long history, making it difficult to create a better design that also addresses all the important features that need to be rebuilt in NextGen CPQ. This challenge mainly arises from its deep integration with the Zuora billing system and its design to handle the complexities of Subscription Lifecycle Management. In support of the architecture work, which aims to take a fresh look at the challenges, this document will provide guidance on the high-priority functional requirements that the new architecture must meet. The product manager emphasizes the need for an architectural solution that directly tackles these complexities, enabling future performance and scalability, functional completeness for high- and medium-priority features, and ease of use. This document outlines the functional focus of NextGen CPQ.

# Area Description Priority 1 Handling of various Charge Types

dmins can create products and bundles that have a mix (combination) of charge types.  Charge types are one-time, recurring, and usage.  Current Challenge: ? High 1.1 Charge Type: One-time Needs to be paid in one sum.  Usually used to reflect the activation of a product and plan, or the setting up (provisioning) of services.Current Challenge: A product with a plan that has only this type of charge is also available to be added as an OLI (See Order Line Item).  Using this construct to represent price for products that have just a one-time price is overkill and confusing when setting up products and when adding pro

ucts. High 1.2 Charge Type Recurring Needs to be paid on a regular basis. Can have different types of periodicity.  Customers cannot define their own periodicity. Current Challenge: ? High 1.3 Charge Type: Usage Payment is determined based on consumption or usage. Current Challenge: The quote has no extended prices for such charges (as u
age is not known during quoting time), but Zuora wants to provide usage estimates based on past usage, projected usage based on industry or similar account, and estimated usage provided by the

ustomer. High 1.3.1 Negotiate prices for a usage-based charge Usage-based charges allow customers to set up Dynamic Pricing with a Rate Card table for that charge.  A sales rep can then negotiate many different price points for one usage charge. Each price point in the Rate Card Table of that charge will later be selected based on pricing-attribute combinations from the actual usage. Current Challenge: The Rate Card Table is not visible in the quote line page.  A sales rep has to get to it in the pricing details.  In the quote line table, the user is not seeing much information for this charge. 2 Charge Models Zuora has 16 different charge models.  All of them need to be supported by NextGen CPQ. See Charge Models Current Challenge: ? High 2.1 Discount Percent Charge Model The discount % charge model is a charge that is added to a

roduct/plan. It can apply to a specific charge or all charges of a product/plan, or apply to the entire subscription, or apply to the entire quote. Current Challenges: It is cumbersome for sales reps to use this charge model as it requires a lot of clicks to set a specific discount % value.  Hence, another mechanism was introduced, the inline discount.  Inline discounts and the Percent Charge Model are similar, but are treated differently in the system (OM and Billing do not have the value of the inline discount; they only get the effective price). 3 Order Line Items Order Line Items (usually hardware that gets paid upfront) are products that do not have a plan.  These products have just one price, no plan, no charge.Current Challenge: OLIs are modeled like subscription products with a plan and a charge,

hich is overkill.  OLIs are listed in a separate section of the quote lines and, as a result, can be out of context/disconnected from an associated product/plan and charged on a subscription.  Handling of OLIs variations by attributes is not supported (Color, Size, Style, etc.) (Xylem).  Handling of large amounts of OLIs is not supported (Xylem). Additional information about OLIs is not captured (Serial Numbers, Ship-to location, Shipment parameters, Shipping cost, routing to Order Mgmt system) Medium High 4 Subscription Lifecycle Management All functionality related to managing the timeline of a subscription and changes over time to the subscription (amendments, renewals) 4.1. Single Subscription in Quote The quote has only one subscription. Current Challenges: Today, the user must determine whether they have a single or multi-subscription quote (Zoom).  A decision must be made at the beginning of the quote process, but what

f the user is unsure whether a single subscription quote could evolve into a multi-subscription quote later? 4.2. New Quote, future-dated actions When creating a new quote, the user can decide to add future-dated actions such as updating a charge item (add more qty, reduce discount, add a product/plan, remove a product/plan).  The user can also add futu

e-dated actions and backdate them into the past.A future-dated update might be based on another earlier future-dated update, and so on.   A future-dated update might be placed in the middle of two future-dated updates.  Current Challenges: Timeline is an additional dimension where changes might have been placed, but it is hard for users to visualize those changes over the timeline and understand fully and quickly what is going on in the quote.Our customers have certain preconceptions about how changes they make in earlier periods should update future-dated updates. E.g., should a qty increase of an earlier update automatically increase the quantity of a segment that has a  future-dated update?) 5 Amendment Quote Quoting of changes to an existing (currently valid and charged) subscription. Removing/adding product/plans, updating charge items (increase, decrease qty, discount, change parameter of billing)Current Challenges: ? 5.1 Amendment quotes, pricing o

items When executing a change to a subscription, customers will want to handle pricing in various ways.Current Challenge: We have configuration settings for how to deal with price updates during amendments.  Take historical price (grandfather in price) and apply to updates (e.g., increase qty with historical price) or fetch the latest and newest price based on quote creation date, amendment service start date, quote valid until date, etc. 5.2. Amendment quotes, business rules Current Challenge: Customers require considerable flexibility in determining the system behavior (enforce biz policies) when executing an amendment.  Example rule from Zoom: after the amendment, the value of the subscription cannot be less than the current subscription value.  The expression power of rules a

d rule performance can be problematic, leading customers to write extension code to handle such business policies. 5.3 Merge/Split of Subscriptions In some cases, when companies merge, split, or reorganise, their subscriptions and entitlements have to be divided into multiple subscriptions or merged into one subscription. This functionality is currently not available in CPQ-X 6 Renewal Quotes Current Challenge: A quote needs

to be autogenerated X days before the renewal.  Can the presentment and acceptance/rejection process by the customer also be handled through automation? 7 Combine new, amendments, and renewals into a single Quote Curren

Challenge: Currently, the new, amend, and renew actions cannot be combined into a single quote, but customers might ask for a change (amendment) in one subscription, want a new subscription, and renew yet another subscription. In this case, the sales rep would need to make 3 separate quotes. 8 Multi Subscription Quote Customers might require an additional dimension to structure product/plans.  For example, they want a si

gle quote, but there are various invoice owners who pay for a subset of product/plans in the quote.  Another example is subscription location. Currently, each location has to be modelled as a subscription, increasing complexity for the sales rep.  Each location might have a slightly different product/plan mix than the next one. Location is not a concept we have, but it is only one example of many where customers are introducing custom fields on the subscription level to model such variation. 9 Cancel Subscription A function is needed to cancel a subscription.  Does this always necessitate a quote?Current Challenge: If the account does not need a quote to confirm the cancellation, why is it necessary for a sales or service r

p to go through all the motions of creating one?  Can we offer a cancel function that sales and service reps can use to cancel a subscription without creating a quote?  Expose the order management function of cancellation to sales and service reps. 10 Billing Parity: Suspend/Resume A function is needed to suspend and resume a subscription.  In essence, setting a status on the subscription to indicate that no further billing will occur, but it also means the se

vice is interrupted. Does this always necessitate a quote? More details here Current Challenge: This function does not exist in CPQ-X yet. 11 'Percent Spent' new Charge Model System needs to calculate the value of this ‘Percent Sepnt’ charge based on a % of the sum of all or a subset of other charges.  An example is that Maintenance and Support cost is 15% of the service subscription price. 12 Commitmen

s in Quote For usage-based charges, accounts might negotiate min and max commitments over some time period.  For example, JP Morgan will commit that over the next month, they will execute bond trades above a minimum amount.  If they don’t meet the minimum amount, JP Morgan has to pay

the minimum amount anyway.  Similar to the maximum amount, the service provider cannot charge more than the agreed-upon maximum commitment amount, which means JP Morgan will never pay more than the maximum amount, regardless of how many bonds they traded. These commitments have various sections (general, periods with commitments, filters for applying to only certain activities/charges).There can be one or more commitments relevant to a quote.  Commitments belong to an agreement.  The agreement and commitments must be displayed in the quote, and how the charge items in the quote are associated with the commitment periods. For some customers (Tradeweb, the), the sales rep must be able to create a new local (to the quote) commitment. For some customers (Tradeweb) sales reps must be able to edit global commitments Current Challenge: Functionality is not implemented in CPQ 13 Billing Parity: Pending Charges 14 Support for Hard Bundles Admin sets up a hard bundle by associating a bundle product with other (component) products.  Pricing is set up for the hard bundle product/plan and charges, and is usually independent from the pricing of its component products.  Accounts can buy a set of products at a better price via a bundle than buying them indivually (incentive).  Sales reps and accounts must understand what products are included in the bundle.  The bundle also has a set of entitlements that might be the union of all entitlements of the component products, but

tlements, features of the bundle product/plan might be an aggregation of the component product features, but that might not always be true. Current Challenges: The Zuora data model, which enables modeling multiple charge items for a product/plan, has been utilized as a workaround to achieve bundling capabilities.  It falls short in pricing and setting discounts on bundle level, as each component is shown with its own price, discount, and qty, which is not how a hard bundle works according to best business practices. 15 Support for Configurable Products Configurable products or dynamic bundles are similar to hard bundles, as they may include products. However, configurable products enable sales reps to undergo a guided configuration process, adding component products or selecting them directly to be added to the configurable products.  Usually used in SaaS for modeling of optional add-ons.  Based on the configuration, the configurable product entitlements are determined, same for features. Sales reps must be able to view included and optional added component products, entitlements, and features.  They must be able to see the total pr

ces for the configurable product and the discount on the configurable product level. 16 Support for building Solutions Building of solutions is similar to configuring products, except solutions do not have a parent product/plan with charges.  A solution is a collection of products that solve a customer's need.  Rules ensure a solution has all the products and that the products work together (are compatible).  There can be multiple solutions in the quote. 17 Support for Price Promotions A price promotion (aka Soft Bundle) is a pricing rules that run across all quote lines and detect if discounts (promotions) can be applied.  A typical price promotion rule might be buy product A and B and get product C for free. Or buy a qty of 2 of product A an

get qty 1 of product B for free. 18 Billing Parity: Upsell Qty 19 Billing Parity: Enhanced Discounts 20 Billing Parity: Ship-to Contact 21 Billing Parity: Invoice grouping 22 Billing Parity: Set bill timing and frequency 23 Billing Parity: Accounting, Revenue, and Taxation fields 24 Billing Parity: Subscription level association of Account concepts, such as Payment Terms, BillTo/SoldTo Contacts,

nvoice Templates 25 Billing Parity: Make changes to a bill schedule 26 Quote Charge Metrics Quote Metrics informs the user from individual charge to quote level about the sub-total (Net) and total (Gross, inclusive all discounts) value.  Quote Metrics shows typical KPIs for subscription quotes like MRR and Delta MRR (Gross, Net, and Discount), TCV (Gross, Net, an

Discount), TCB and Delta TCB (Gross, Net, and Discount), and Delta Qty. Levels:Total and sub-total on charge level Total and sub-total on ramp interval level Total and sub-total on ramp level Total and sub-total on subscription level Total and sub-total on quote levelCurrent Challenges: Metrics are calculated by the billing system and might not always represent the way how a customer would want to see their metrics.  Metric definition and hence their calculation can be specific to the customer’s needs.  Sales reps want to understand the numbers quickly and without breaking out their own calculator, the current display of t

e quote metrics numbers can be difficult to understand. 27 Ramping of subscriptions Sales rep ramp deals in order to meet customer expectations.  For example a customer might ask for a deep discount, the sales rep accommodates that request and applies in the beginning of the subscription the discount.  However he also can model the subscription with ramps to solwly over a given number of ramps phase out the discount.  Similar with adding qty over ramp intervals as accounts usually onboard their users gradually.  Challenge: Future dated updates and making changes to ramps  are in essence the same thing but are initiated in different ways and displayed in different ways.  Currently sales rep are limited in automating the generation of ramps with desired changes. E.g. Make a ramp every 10 days and starte with a discount of 30%, then decrease the discount by 1% for each successive ramp and stop reducing the discount when you reach 10%. Change made for a ramp are not percolating into successive ramps. E.g. If a sales rep increases the qty in ramp 6 of 12 from 1 to 2, he expects that all successive ramps (

Strategic Embed of Plasmic

Company Overview Plasmic provides a unique offering in the market enabling companies to build both production-grade websites or rich (backoffice) web apps by combining visual editing (no-code) with deep integration into developer code-bases (pro-code). Our intent is to embed their technology either as an open source foundation through commercial agreement into Zuora Experience Builder.

Plasmic was founded in 2019 by Yang Zhang (now at Anthropic) and Chung Wu (now at Databricks). Plasmic has raised $11M in total funding. Their seed round in May 2021 raised $4M, led by New Enterprise Associates. The company is currently run by Jason Long with an 11 person team predominantly off-shore. Their unique position supporting both backend and frontend technologies appears to be the result of a strategic misalignment rather than targeted strategy. They started as a back office builder application and realized they could only take it so far without pro-code, and realized that the space was getting saturated with “AI App Builders” so they switched their attention to experiences as they struggled to find true market fit and growth. They offer advanced versions of their solution that includes AI features while the core platform is available as open source under copyleft AGPL and MIT guidelines.

As outlined in this document, Plasmic provides the best option for Zuora’s Experience Build

r, but poses unique risks which we believe can be mitigated.

Zuora SKUs that Plasmic Will Enable and Accelerate Time-to-market

Plasmic will provide the foundation for Zuora Experience Builder which will also provide the foundation for, or replace additional SKUs as follows:

Zuora Experiences

Storefront

Customer Portal

Back-office Experiences

Zephr Experiences

Forms

Paywall

My Account (Customer Portal)

Zuora Subscriber Portal (Replace/migrate to Zuora Experiences Customer Portal)

There are 62 customers on Zuora’s legacy Subscriber Portal with a fresh pipeline of over 37 cross-sell or new customers that desire this new Experiences solution. This li

t represents over $63.2M of total existing ACV.

Example customers include Toyota Motor Credit Corporation, TOYOTA ARGENTINA S.A., Staples Canada ULC, MarketWise, LLC(fka Beacon Street Services LLC), Zoom Communications, Inc., Merck & Co., Inc., Spruce Power, GitLab, Inc., MarginEdge, Visma Software International AS, Absorb Software Inc., Venn Inc (fka OS33), GlobalVision, PDI Software, Subaru of America, Inc., QHR Technologies, Inc., Caterpillar Inc., orderbird GmbH, Authentic8, Inc., UPKEEP TECHNOLOGIES, INC, Veradigm LLC, Valant Medical Solutions Inc., 66degrees, ConnectWise, LLC, Philips Electronics Nederland B.V., InPlay, Intralinks Inc., Bexio AG, Bonnier News AB, Outreach.io, Accertify, Inc., TimeClock Plus, LLC ( fka Shiftplanning / Humanity.com ), Teledyne FLIR, LLC, NZX Limited, Bigcommerce Holdings, Inc., Amazing Life, inOne, News Corp Australia, Asset Panda, Veriforce, Now NZ, Dental Intelligence, AutoHook (by Urban Science), Canopy Tax, Carl Zeiss AG, Compagnie Nationale du Rhône, Enercare Inc., Delta Defense, LLC, Vonage, Trader Corp, Aims 360, Paycor, Inc., Elm Street Technology, LLC, ZOLL Data Systems Inc, Convirza, Homecare Homebase, LLC, LivePerson, Inc., GolfNow, LLC, Procore Technologies, Inc., AIB, Inc., Invoca, Home Care Pulse, Toast, Inc., Mavenlink, EZLynx, Pearson Education Inc., Stenograph LLC, PureSky Community Solar Inc., Data Processing Design Inc, RPost, Inc., Pie Insurance Services, Inc., Flexe, CarGurus Inc, Akerna Corp (fka MJ Freeway), OVH US LLC, Editshare, LLC, 15Five, Inc., Vimeo, Rent Group Inc., ESTENDO SPA, Doosan Bobcat North America, Inc, Assessio, Sound-Eklin, International Risk Management Institute, Inc., Reuters News & Media Ltd, PagerDuty, Inc., Unity Technologies SF, Fullsteam LLC, Atmosera (EasyStreet), ItaliaOnLine S.p.a., Capital One Services, LLC - (Capital One Auto) (Jan 6 Tenant ID), GEDI Digital S.r.l., Legal Software Developments Pty Limited, ZenQMS, Vebra Solutions Limited, PropertyVista, Petvisor Holdings, LLC, Leafly, LLC, Resy Networks Inc. Experiences Customer Tracker

Business Case

Zuora will initially sign a 1-yr contract for up to 50 Commercial Customers at a cost of $50,000 with a fee of $1,000 for each additional customer. This will eliminate AGPL restrictions while also providing Zuora with AI enhancements. All hosting, management, and support will be provided by Zuora.

With over 90 deals in our pipeline and a massive pent up demand, we expect to generate between $17-25M of incremental revenue over the three year term. This is based on the new

Experiences SKU beginning at $37,500 ($17,500 discounted) and ramping up to $125,000 ($62,500 discounted). Despite downward pricing pressures in the market, this is a very competitive price point and we expect to meet or exceed these business commitments.

Zuora can deploy Plasmic under the open-source license, however the marginal impact of 2.7% COGS we have negotiated mitigates legal risk and ensures long term protection in case of an acquisition.

Business Case Year 1 Year 2 Year 3 Year 4 Penetration 81 162 243 406 Zuora Revenue (ARR) $3,041,250 $6,082,500 $9,123,750 $15,206,250 Zuora Net Revenue (ARR-COGS) $2,960,150 $5,920,300 $8,880,450 $14,800,750 Plasmic Revenue $81,100 $162,200 $243,300 $405,500

Source: Baseline Business Case

Licence Benefits

While plasmic is open source and will suite our use case, the additional benefits of a license agreement are:

Remove AGPL license

Onboarding services

Dedicated slack channel

SLA for bug fixes (P1 classification and response time)

Also if we find an issue in AGPL ensuring that we can push change

Long term support for backend integrations

AI-enabled page builder and component builder

Influence over Plasmic’s roadmap. While we don’t have any immediate requests for them from a roadmap perspective, this will ensure long term alignment. I do anticipate us co-developing a first class Plasmic-Zuora connector, similar to what they have with Shopify/Saelor/etc., to make available to any of their customers, including on their website, etc.

Code sharing pipeline. They have agreed to include any and all of their private code to us with a license agreement.

Ensure no long term restrictions are imposed such as page views, MMSC, or other C2 (end-customer) metrics

Plasmic’s Product

Plasmic’s product uniquely meets Zuora’s requirements for building modern, responsive user experiences that integrate with Zuora (and other systems) and can be deployed easily and natively within our customer’s existing technology stack.



Key features relevant for Zuora:

Responsive design - supporting web & mobile.

Supports vari

us audience expertise levels building pages from no-code drag-and-drop to pro-code custom components and coding.

Deploys natively to customer’s existing tech stacks, supporting React, JS, REST APIs, Shopify, Wordpress, and more. This allows us to support any customer, from SMB to large enterprises.

Integrates easily with Zuora and other systems.

Allows us to easily and organically build templates, components, sections, etc so that customers can have a better starting point and less customization required.

Allows self-hosting

Is open source

Allows customers to use their own style tokens and classes.

Already supports advanced features, like scheduling of changes, A/B testing, analytics, AI, figma import, multiplayer editing, branching, and more.

Technical Evaluation

Almost every similar solution falls into two categories:

CMS/website builder - These are very ni

e, figma-like website design solutions, but lack any/all integration abilities. They are purely visual/SSG (Static site generation).

App builders - These are almost all designed for “internal” app building and have good support for integrating with other systems. They mostly lack responsive design and lack the ability to handle webscale. They typically do not come with their own APIs to interact with the experiences, and depend on internal user interaction.

Plasmic was intentionally designed to be the best of both of those types of solutions. It combines the nice design interface, integrations with other systems, APIs and the ability to deploy/export code, and allows for our infrastructure to handle the scale as it is self-hosted. Also, unlike many other similar solutions, Plasmic is open source and allows for self-hosting, which allows us to fully control the deployment, infrastructure, security, and customization for our needs.

We evaluated many other platforms:

Webflow

UIBakery

Cloudcannon

Divhunt

Builder.io

Puck

Craft.js

Webcrumbs

ShipCode

Web10

Wavemaker

Bubble.io

Retool

….and o

hers

A very good comparison of Plasmic vs these other platforms.

Risks & Mitigation

Bankruptcy Risk

Plasmic's current financial position presents a moderate bankruptcy risk. The company has raised $11M in total funding with their last known round in May 2021, and they are experiencing difficulty finding product-market fit as evidenced by multiple strategic pivots. The departure of both co-founders (Yang Zhang to Anthropic, Chung Wu to Databricks) and their ongoing struggle to establish a clear GTM motion further elevate this concern. Should Plasmic cease operations, Zuora could face disruption to product roadmap, loss of enhancements and bug fixes, and potential support burden.

Mitigation: Our 5-year source code rights provide a critical safety net, enabling Zuora to fork and maintain the codebase independently if needed. Additionally, the core platform's AGPL open-source license allows us to continue using and developing the technology without commercial restrictions as a fallback position. Our technical architecture explicitly isolates the Plasmic layer, making it feasible to transition to an alternative solution or maintain the platform internally with our engineering team. The relatively small initial investment ($50K annually with $1K per additional customer) limits our financial exposure.

Acquisition Risk

The visual

uilder/low-code space is experiencing rapid consolidation, making Plasmic an attractive acquisition target for larger platform players (Adobe, Salesforce, Microsoft, etc.) or emerging AI-native competitors. An acquisition could result in unfavorable licensing changes, substantial price increases, product discontinuation, or strategic redirection that misaligns with Zuora's needs. The acquirer may choose to sunset the standalone product in favor of integrating features into their existing platform.

Mitigation: Our negotiated 5-year source code rights protect Zuora regardless of ownership changes, providing continuity even under new ownership. The technical isolation strategy enables us to swap out Plasmic for an alternative solution without major architectural changes. Our commercial agreement locks in pricing for committed customer counts, limiting exposure to price increases. The AGPL open-source core provides an ultimate fallback, allowing us to maintain a community-supported version if the commercial relationship deteriorates post-acquisition.

Conclusion

We believe that we have truly found a diamond in the rough. In a bifurcated ma

ketplace with CMS-based website builders that are highly error prone, and application builders that require extensive coding, we have found a solution that elegantly solves both issues. Their lack of market traction is solely based on their inability to understand market conditions and effectively GTM at scale. They lack clear strategic direction, a dedicated GTM motion, and never developed the channel and partner relationships necessary to scale. Through commercial term mitigation, we believe we have a powerful and stable solution for our customers. ### Optimization Strategy **What it is:** Decisions about which offers to show to which customers, when, and how.

Each layer builds on the one below. Each can be sold separately, but together they're more powerful.

### Capability 1: Smart Context Detection

**What it does**: Automatically figures out who the customer is and what they should see.

**The problem it solves**: Today, if you sell in multiple countries with different pricing, you need to: - Manually configure pricing for each location - Update multiple systems when anything changes - Hope everything stays in sync

**How our solution works**: 1. Customer visits your website from Germany 2. System automatically detects: Location \= Germany, Channel \= Website, Customer Type \= New Visitor 3. System applies: Euro pricing, German terms, appropriate product catalog 4. Customer sees the right offer instantly

**Real example - Healthcare Company**: - **Before**: Must charge 10% premium for HIPAA-compliant storage. This requires manually updating pricing across four systems. Takes days. Easy to make mistakes. - **After**: Set rule once: "If Healthcare customer, add 10%". Applies automatically. Updates everywhere instantly.

**Why this matters**: - Set up new regions in minutes instead of weeks - Never show wrong prices to customers - Change strategy instantly (raise prices, run promotions, launch bundles)

### Capability 2: Flexible Product Management

**What it does**: Easy tools to create bundles, packages, tiered offerings, and promotions.

**The problem it solves**: Today, creating a bundle like "Professional Package \= Software + Support + Training" requires: - Custom coding - Separate setup in each system - Hard to change once created - Difficult to show relationships between products

**How our solution works**:

**Packages** - Pre-built combinations: - Create "Startup Bundle" \= Product A + Product B + Support - Set package price (can be different from individual prices) - Add package-level discount - Done - available everywhere automatically

**Bundles** - Customer choice: - Create "Pick 3 Channels" from 10 available options - Set rules: minimum 2, maximum 5 - Price each option differently - Let customers build their own plan

**Features** - Building blocks: - Define what features exist (Lock/Unlock, Super Cruise, Premium Support) - Attach pricing to features - Combine features into products flexibly

**Real example - GM OnStar**: - **Before**: Every new feature requires creating new product in system. Want to bundle "Super Cruise + Security + Apps"? Requires engineering work to connect them. - **After**: Define bundle rules: "Super Cruise only available with Premium package". Create promotional bundle: "Super Cruise launch: 20% off when combined with annual plan". Launch in minutes.

**Why this matters**: - Marketing can test new packages

### Capability 3: Seamless Buying Experience

**What it does**: Let customers discover, compare, configure, buy, and manage subscriptions themselves.

**The problem it solves**: Today, customers expect to: - Browse and compare options online - Configure exactly what they need - Buy without talking to sales - Change their subscription themselves

But complex subscriptions require sales involvement because the systems aren't built for self-service.

**How our solution works**:

**Discovery**: Show the right products to each customer - Based on their location, company size, current subscriptions - Highlight relevant bundles and packages - Smart recommendations

**Comparison**: Help them understand options - Clear feature comparison - Show upgrade paths - Explain what they get at each tier

**Configuration**: Build what they need - Select products from available bundles - Choose add-ons - See price update in real-time

**Purchase**: Complete transaction - Handle payment - Apply promotions automatically - Create subscription immediately

**Management**: Let them modify later - Upgrade/downgrade plans - Add/remove features - Update payment methods - All within contract terms

**Real example - QHR Technologies**: - **Before**: Customers call sales to configure, get quote, complete purchase. Takes days. High abandonment. - **After**: Customers browse packages (Doctor Package, Clinic Package), configure based on their province, add optional features, purchase online. Complete in minutes.

**Why this matters**: - Reduce sales cycle time - Increase conversion rates - Lower cost per sale - Better customer experience

## EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

**The Core Idea:** Build Zuora as a platform that takes a customer from **$50 million to a couple of billion** through their entire lifecycle - from self-serve beginnings to complex enterprise needs - **without requiring them to rip out systems and start over.**

**The Strategic Shift:** From siloed product roadmaps to **"building the intersection"** - where products connect and where customers actually experience Zuora.

**The Fundamental Insight:** > "In Zuora, there are two product motions. There's a product motion: build a roadmap. But there's a second product motion: **build the intersection**. That's the platform. Build as the customer sees you, which is at the intersection. No one has typically owned the intersection. When you make the intersection a roadmap, that's when you build platform."

---
